content.title: Vestibular Neuritis
content.summary: Vestibular neuritis is an acute peripheral vestibular syndrome caused by inflammation of the vestibular nerve, presenting with acute onset severe vertigo, nausea, vomiting, and gait instability lasting days to weeks. Unlike labyrinthitis, hearing is preserved. Treatment is supportive with vestibular rehabilitation.
key_points: Acute onset vertigo lasting days; typically post-viral; hearing preserved (unlike labyrinthitis)
Unidirectional horizontal-torsional nystagmus beating away from affected ear; suppressed by fixation
HINTS exam differentiates from central causes: peripheral = HI-negative, N-unidirectional, TS-negative
Head impulse test positive (catch-up saccade) toward affected side indicates peripheral lesion
Treatment: symptomatic (meclizine, ondansetron) acutely; vestibular rehabilitation for recovery
Prognosis: most recover; 50% have residual vestibular hypofunction; some develop BPPV later
content.statement: Vestibular neuritis is a common cause of acute vertigo that can mimic posterior circulation stroke. The HINTS exam is critical for distinguishing peripheral from central causes at bedside.

explanation.intuition: The vestibular nerve normally provides symmetric input from both labyrinths. Acute inflammation of one vestibular nerve creates sudden asymmetry, interpreted by the brain as rotation (vertigo). The brain receives normal input from one side and reduced input from the affected side, generating nystagmus beating toward the stronger (normal) side.
explanation.key_insight: HINTS exam is more sensitive than early MRI for posterior circulation stroke in acute vestibular syndrome. A 'peripheral' pattern (positive head impulse, direction-fixed nystagmus, no skew) essentially rules out stroke. A 'central' pattern (negative head impulse, direction-changing nystagmus, skew deviation) mandates stroke workup.
explanation.technical_details: Head Impulse Test (HI): brisk head rotation toward affected side produces catch-up saccade (positive = peripheral). Nystagmus (N): direction-fixed, horizontal-torsional, beats away from lesion (peripheral). Test of Skew (TS): alternating cover test; vertical deviation suggests central. HINTS: HI-N-TS; one central finding = stroke until proven otherwise.

definitions_glossary.vestibular_neuritis: Inflammation of vestibular nerve causing acute vertigo without hearing loss; usually post-viral
definitions_glossary.labyrinthitis: Inflammation affecting both vestibular and cochlear portions; vertigo WITH hearing loss
definitions_glossary.acute_vestibular_syndrome: Acute onset vertigo lasting >24 hours with nausea/vomiting; differential includes peripheral and central causes
definitions_glossary.hints_exam: Head Impulse, Nystagmus, Test of Skew: bedside exam differentiating peripheral from central vertigo
definitions_glossary.head_impulse_test: Rapid head rotation with eye fixation; catch-up saccade indicates peripheral vestibular lesion
definitions_glossary.nystagmus: Involuntary rhythmic eye movements; direction defined by fast phase
definitions_glossary.direction_fixed_nystagmus: Nystagmus direction unchanged with gaze; suggests peripheral lesion
definitions_glossary.direction_changing_nystagmus: Nystagmus reverses direction with gaze; suggests central lesion
definitions_glossary.skew_deviation: Vertical misalignment of eyes from brainstem lesion; suggests central cause
definitions_glossary.vestibular_rehabilitation: Physical therapy exercises to promote central compensation for vestibular hypofunction
definitions_glossary.canal_paresis: Reduced vestibular response on caloric testing; confirms peripheral vestibulopathy
definitions_glossary.post_viral_neuritis: Presumed viral etiology (HSV reactivation) following upper respiratory infection

pathophysiology.mechanism: Vestibular neuritis is thought to result from viral inflammation (likely HSV-1 reactivation) of the vestibular nerve, particularly the superior division. Acute damage causes sudden loss of tonic vestibular input from one side. The vestibular nuclei receive asymmetric input, generating the sensation of rotation and nystagmus. Over days to weeks, central compensation restores balance.
key_pathways: Sudden unilateral vestibular hypofunction → asymmetric input to vestibular nuclei
Asymmetric vestibular nuclei activity → nystagmus + vertigo
Central compensation over weeks → gradual recovery
pathophysiology.clinical_significance: Vestibular neuritis is benign but causes significant morbidity. The main clinical challenge is distinguishing it from posterior circulation stroke, which can present identically but requires emergent treatment.

clinical_features.vertigo: Severe, acute onset, continuous, lasting days; worse with head movement
clinical_features.gait_instability: Falls toward affected side; improves over days
clinical_features.timing: Often follows viral illness by 1-2 weeks

hints_exam.head_impulse: POSITIVE (catch-up saccade) toward affected side = peripheral
hints_exam.nystagmus: Direction-FIXED, horizontal-torsional, beats AWAY from lesion, suppressed by fixation = peripheral
hints_exam.central_pattern: HI negative, N direction-changing, TS positive = stroke

diagnostic_studies.clinical_diagnosis: HINTS exam sufficient if experienced examiner; more sensitive than MRI in first 24-48h
diagnostic_studies.mri_dwi: If central features on HINTS; may be falsely negative early in stroke
diagnostic_studies.caloric_testing: Reduced response on affected side (canal paresis); confirms vestibular hypofunction

vestibular_suppressants.note: Use for max 48-72h; prolonged use delays central compensation

corticosteroids.rationale: May improve vestibular recovery by reducing nerve inflammation
corticosteroids.evidence: Modest benefit in some trials; not universally recommended
corticosteroids.regimen: If used: methylprednisolone taper over 3 weeks

vestibular_rehabilitation.timing: Begin early, after acute symptoms subside
vestibular_rehabilitation.exercises: Gaze stabilization, balance training, habituation exercises
vestibular_rehabilitation.efficacy: Strong evidence for improving balance and reducing dizziness
vestibular_rehabilitation.duration: Several weeks to months depending on deficit severity

prognosis.acute_phase: Severe symptoms 1-3 days, then gradual improvement
prognosis.recovery: Most recover well; 50% have residual vestibular hypofunction (often asymptomatic)
prognosis.complications: ~15% develop BPPV (from otolith displacement); rare recurrence

skos.definition: An acute inflammatory disorder of the vestibular nerve causing sudden onset severe vertigo without hearing loss, typically following viral infection

learning_objectives: Perform the HINTS exam to differentiate peripheral from central vertigo
Recognize the clinical features of vestibular neuritis
Apply appropriate acute symptomatic treatment for vestibular neuritis
clinical_pearls: HINTS exam is more sensitive than MRI for stroke in first 24-48h of acute vertigo
Hearing preserved = vestibular neuritis; hearing loss = labyrinthitis
Direction-fixed nystagmus beating AWAY from lesion = peripheral
Positive head impulse (catch-up saccade) = peripheral = reassuring
Limit vestibular suppressants to 48-72h to avoid delaying central compensation
~15% develop BPPV weeks later from otolith displacement into canals
common_misconceptions: CT/MRI should be first-line for acute vertigo (HINTS is more sensitive early)
Vestibular neuritis = labyrinthitis (labyrinthitis has hearing loss)
Negative head impulse is reassuring (negative = CENTRAL = concerning)
